section.label: THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS
section.fragment: Management of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is principally based upon the following: Identification of children with VUR.

section.label: THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS
section.fragment: Identifying and managing children with bladder and bowel dysfunction.

section.label: THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS
section.fragment: Therapeutic interventions include medical therapy (ie, antibiotic prophylaxis), treatment of comorbid conditions such as voiding dysfunction, and surgical correction.

section.label: THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS
section.fragment: Clinical trials comparing the two approaches demonstrate a decrease in the incidence of pyelonephritis with surgical intervention, but no significant difference in the risk of developing subsequent new renal scars, hypertension, or chronic kidney disease.

section.label: Medical treatment
section.fragment: Medical therapy for VUR consists of daily prophylactic administration of antibiotics.

section.label: Medical treatment
section.fragment: Antimicrobial agents most commonly used for prophylaxis include trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, trimethoprim alone, or nitrofurantoin.

section.label: Medical treatment
section.fragment: Amoxicillin and cephalosporins are not recommended because of the increased likelihood of resistant organisms, except in infants below two months of age.

section.label: Medical treatment
section.fragment: Adverse effects of sulfonamides, trimethoprim, or nitrofurantoin preclude their use in infants less than two months of age.

section.label: Medical treatment
section.fragment: Other concerns related to medical therapy include compliance, breakthrough infection, and the need for monitoring of VUR by either contrast voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) or radionuclide cystogram (RNC).

section.label: Medical treatment
section.fragment: VCUG and RNC are both invasive procedures that require bladder catheterization.

section.label: Medical treatment
section.fragment: In one study of 51 low-risk (no voiding abnormalities or renal scarring) older children (mean age 8.6 years) with grades I to IV VUR, cessation of prophylactic antibiotics resulted in no new renal scarring measured one year later by dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) renal scan.

section.label: Surgical treatment
section.fragment: The two surgical approaches used are open surgical reimplantation and endoscopic correction.

section.label: Open surgical reimplantation
section.fragment: Open surgical reimplantation of ureters is a highly successful procedure, with reported correction rates of 95 to 99 percent regardless of the severity of VUR.

section.label: Robotic assisted laparoscopic reimplantation
section.fragment: Two case series reported comparable success rates between children who underwent robotic assisted reimplantation compared with patients undergoing open surgical correction during the same time periods.

section.label: Robotic assisted laparoscopic reimplantation
section.fragment: Further studies are needed to determine the relative cost/benefit of robotic assisted reimplantation versus open surgical reimplantation.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: The STING procedure was modified to include submucosal injection in the distal ureter, which may require distention of the ureter with irrigating fluid, referred to as HIT (hydrodistention implantation technique).

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: Multiple regression analysis demonstrated that preoperative VUR grade was the single most important factor affecting outcome: Grade I: 89 percent (95% CI, 69-90 percent).

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: The success rate of a second STING procedure after an initial failed injection appears to be good.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: The success rate for both initial and subsequent endoscopic correction is lower in patients with grade V reflux.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: This was illustrated in a case series of 132 children with grade V reflux, in whom VUR was completely resolved in 88 (53 percent) ureters and decreased in severity in 26 (16 percent) ureters after the first procedure, and in 36 (22 percent) and 10 (6 percent) after the second and third injection, respectively.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: The STING also has been utilized as a salvage procedure correcting VUR in 65 percent of patients who failed a previous open surgical reimplantation.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: Endoscopic correction has also been successfully used in patients with VUR associated with paraureteral diverticula (also known as Hutch diverticula).

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: In contrast, endoscopic correction has not been successful in patients with refluxing megaureter with distal aperistaltic segments, and is less successful in those with bladder and bowel dysfunction.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: Ureteral obstruction - In a retrospective review of 745 patients with 1155 ureters who underwent correction, the incidence of postoperative ureteral obstruction was less than 1 percent of treated patients.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: Postprocedure urinary tract infection (UTI) and VUR recurrence - In a retrospective review of 167 children who underwent endoscopic correction, 40 patients (24 percent) developed a UTI at a median follow-up of 32 months postprocedure.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: One-half of these patients with UTIs were febrile with their infection.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: Repeat cystography was performed in 18 patients with postprocedure UTI (15 with fever and 3 without fever) and VUR was noted in seven patients, all of whom had febrile UTI.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: In this cohort, multivariate analysis demonstrated that febrile UTI was more likely in patients who were female and had bladder and bowel dysfunction (either pre- or postoperative).

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: Although the rates of successful correction with the endoscopic approach STING do not yet approach that of an open procedure and the long-term outcome of the endoscopic approach is uncertain, the minimal invasiveness of the procedure makes it an attractive alternative for patients with less severe grades of reflux.

section.label: Endoscopic correction
section.fragment: As an example, in the Swedish Reflux Trial of 203 children between one and two years of age with VUR grade III to IV, there was a 71 percent resolution of VUR in those patients assigned to endoscopic correction.

section.label: Voiding dysfunction
section.fragment: Voiding (bladder and bowel) dysfunction, referred to as bladder bowel dysfunction (BBD) in the 2010 revised American Urologic Association Guidelines, prolongs the time for VUR resolution, and is associated with an increased risk of breakthrough infection and reduced success of endoscopic surgery.

section.label: Voiding dysfunction
section.fragment: These patients can have difficulties in both bowel and bladder elimination.

section.label: Voiding dysfunction
section.fragment: In a cohort of 347 toilet-trained children with VUR from a single tertiary center, 298 patients underwent urodynamic evaluation as part of the standard practice evaluation at this institution.

section.label: Voiding dysfunction
section.fragment: There was a history of symptomatic lower urinary tract symptoms in 37 percent of the patients, who were younger, were more likely to have an urodynamic study demonstrating voiding dysfunction (particularly evidence of an overactive bladder), and had milder VUR than the overall cohort.

section.label: Voiding dysfunction
section.fragment: In a baseline study, bowel and bladder dysfunction was identified in 56 percent of 126 toilet-trained children (<6 years of age) enrolled in the randomized intervention for VUR (RIVUR) trial comparing antibiotic prophylaxis and placebo in children with grades I to IV VUR.

section.label: Voiding dysfunction
section.fragment: Aggressive treatment with bladder training can both improve bladder function and lead to VUR resolution including some patients with grade V reflux.

section.label: CHOICE OF THERAPY
section.fragment: Historically, either medical or surgical intervention has been the recommended treatment in children with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).

section.label: CHOICE OF THERAPY
section.fragment: There are limited data comparing the effect of treatment versus no treatment (ie, surveillance) of VUR on renal outcome (ie, chronic kidney disease and renal scarring).

section.label: CHOICE OF THERAPY
section.fragment: In contrast, there are several clinical trials that demonstrate similar renal outcome in patients treated with either prophylactic antibiotics or surgical correction.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: A surveillance regimen and prompt treatment of intercurrent episodes of urinary tract infection (UTI) may be as effective as medical or surgical intervention in children with VUR, particularly in those with low-grade reflux (ie, grades I through II).

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: In particular, the premise that antimicrobial prophylaxis is more effective than surveillance in the prevention of recurrent UTI and acute pyelonephritis in children with VUR has been increasingly questioned.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: A meta-analysis of individual data in infants and young children (2 to 24 months) without VUR and with grades I to IV VUR did not detect an overall benefit for prophylaxis in preventing recurrent UTI.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: As an example, in patients with grade IV VUR, the risk of recurrent infection for patients treated medically versus by surveillance alone was 29 versus 43 percent, but did not differ statistically (relative risk 0.73, 95% CI 0.39-1.35).

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: In addition, there were no data presented for patients with grade V VUR.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: In patients with grade I to III VUR, several trials have reported no difference in the rate of UTI or renal scarring between medical intervention (prophylactic antibiotics) and surveillance as illustrated by the following studies.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: In the first unblinded study of 236 children between 3 months and 18 years of age with acute pyelonephritis (APN), 113 patients with mild VUR (grade I [n = 19], grade II [n = 57], and grade III [n = 37]), and 115 patients without VUR were randomly assigned to receive prophylactic antibiotics or no prophylaxis.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: Prophylactic antibiotic therapy in children with low-grade VUR did not decrease the recurrence of either cystitis or APN, or the rate of renal scarring.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: In the second study of 225 children between one month and three years of age with grades I through III VUR, patients were randomly assigned to receive prophylactic cotrimoxazole or placebo.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: There was no difference in the incidence of UTI and febrile UTI after 18-month follow-up between the overall groups who received prophylaxis or placebo (17 versus 26 percent) or in subgroups based upon the severity of their reflux.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: There appeared to be an association with gender, as prophylactic antibiotics reduced recurrent infection in boys, particularly those with Grade III reflux.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: These results suggest that prophylactic antibiotic therapy may prevent infection with higher grades of reflux, particularly in boys.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: In a third study of 338 patients with urinary tract infections, a subset analysis of the 128 patients demonstrated no difference in the rate of repeat febrile UTI in patients who received prophylactic antibiotics versus no prophylaxis (12 versus 20 percent).

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: the reduction in absolute risk was greatest for children with grade III to V VUR (6.8 percentage points compared with 5.4 percentage points for children with grade I to II VUR and 1.8 percentage points for children without VUR).

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: In children with grade III and IV VUR, data from a Swedish trial demonstrated medical or surgical treatment was more effective than surveillance alone in reducing the risk of febrile UTIs and renal damage in children with grades III and IV VUR.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: In this study, 203 children between one and two years of age with VUR grade III to IV were randomly assigned to one of three treatment regimens: antibiotic prophylaxis, endoscopic correction, and surveillance with antibiotic treatment for acute infection.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: This difference was primarily due to the higher rate of UTI in girls compared with that in boys (33 versus 9 percent).

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: New renal damage as detected by dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) renal scan occurred in 0, 9, and 13 percent of patients in the prophylactic, endoscopic, and surveillance groups, respectively.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: In a retrospective study from a single tertiary center in the United States, 224 of 529 eligible patients with VUR were managed with surveillance alone.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: Patients managed off antibiotic therapy were older, had milder VUR, were less likely to present with a febrile UTI, and had lower bladder/bowel dysfunction scores.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: As noted above, an ongoing trial in the United States of children with VUR (randomized intervention for VUR [RIVUR] trial) comparing trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) prophylaxis and placebo in 607 children (two months to six years) with grades I to IV VUR following UTI will hopefully add more information that will answer the question of whether the use of prophylactic antibiotics provides any benefits for patients with reflux.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: Based on the above discussion, prophylactic antibiotics do not appear to be more effective than surveillance alone in reducing the rate of infection or renal scarring in children with mild VUR (grade I and II).

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: However, it remains uncertain whether intervention is beneficial in preventing recurrent UTI and renal scarring in patients with higher grade VUR.

section.label: Intervention versus surveillance/placebo trials
section.fragment: Until data exist that demonstrate conclusively similar renal outcomes (chronic kidney disease and renal scarring) with or without treatment in children with grade III, IV, and V reflux, we continue to treat children with moderate or high-grade VUR.

section.label: Medical versus surgical therapy
section.fragment: Data from clinical trials and a systematic review have demonstrated comparable renal outcome in patients treated with either prophylactic antibiotics or surgical correction.

section.label: Medical versus surgical therapy
section.fragment: The choice of therapy does not impact the renal outcome (ie, renal scarring and impaired renal function) in children with severe bilateral disease who are at increased risk for end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and hypertension (HTN).

section.label: Medical versus surgical therapy
section.fragment: This was illustrated in one of the included trials that evaluated medical versus surgical therapy in a group of 52 children with severe bilateral VUR, radiological evidence of renal scarring, and a mean glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of 72.4 mL/min per 1.73 m2.

section.label: Medical versus surgical therapy
section.fragment: At 10-year follow-up, overall ESRD developed in four patients and HTN in seven patients.

section.label: Medical versus surgical therapy
section.fragment: There were no differences in renal function, or in the incidence of HTN and ESRD in patients based upon whether they received medical or surgical management.

section.label: Medical versus surgical therapy
section.fragment: Based upon the lack of evidence suggesting a difference between medical and surgical therapies, the clinician should provide parents with information regarding the benefits and limitations of the different therapeutic options.

section.label: OUR APPROACH
section.fragment: Prior to surgical correction for VUR, patients with voiding dysfunction should be identified because inadequately treated voiding dysfunction will lead to failure of surgical VUR correction and an increased risk of urinary tract infection (UTI).

section.label: Grades III to V
section.fragment: Our approach is as follows: All patients with grades III to V VUR regardless of age receive antibiotic prophylaxis.

section.label: Grades III to V
section.fragment: A trial of therapeutic medical intervention should be provided before any surgical intervention is undertaken as the surgical failure rate is significant in patients with persistent voiding dysfunction.

section.label: Grades III to V
section.fragment: Grade V reflux in children over six years of age.

section.label: Grade I and II
section.fragment: Medical therapy - Although several studies have suggested that prophylactic antibiotics may not be an effective intervention in reducing the rate of infection or renal scarring in children with mild VUR, families may choose medical therapy especially in patients who are at risk for urinary tract infections (eg, those with voiding dysfunction) or in infants, who are unable to communicate symptoms in the presence of an infection.

section.label: Grade I and II
section.fragment: In particular, prophylactic antibiotic therapy should be considered in patients with voiding dysfunction because of their increased risk of infection.

section.label: Grade I and II
section.fragment: Surgical correction - We do not routinely suggest surgical correction in patients with mild VUR because there is a high likelihood of spontaneous resolution and a low risk of renal scarring.

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: Mandatory urine cultures and urinalysis are required whenever there are urinary symptoms suggestive of UTI or unexplained fever.

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: Monitoring of reflux is done by either contrast voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) or radionuclide cystogram (RNC).

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: Although there is little supportive evidence for the timing of follow-up for reflux for patients on medical therapy, evaluation is recommended every 12 to 18 months.

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: If the reflux is severe in the older child, the interval between imaging studies is increased to 18 months to 2 years because of the lower likelihood of spontaneous resolution.

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: One study has utilized a decision-tree model analysis to determine the optimal timing of follow-up for VCUG in patients treated with prophylactic antibiotics, and recommended that follow-up cystograms can be scheduled every two years in children with grades I and II reflux and every three years in those with grades III or higher.

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: Renal ultrasonography can be used to monitor renal growth and detect the presence of gross scarring.

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: In our practice, renal ultrasounds are routinely performed annually in patients who are medically treated.

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: The American Urology Association (AUA) guidelines suggest that selective monitoring for renal scarring by dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) renal scan is advised for patients at risk for significant abnormalities that may affect their care.

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: In our practice, we routinely obtain DMSA renal scans in patients with grade III to V reflux.

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: DMSA renal scans are also obtained in patients with breakthrough infections, abnormal renal function, or an abnormal renal ultrasound.

section.label: Surveillance and medical therapy
section.fragment: As an example, a child who is managed by observation may be changed to prophylactic antibiotics, whereas surgical correction may be considered in a child already on antibiotic prophylaxis.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: There is a paucity of data addressing when medical therapy should be discontinued in patients initially treated with prophylactic antibiotics.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: In one retrospective study of 110 children (mean age 5.4 years), prophylactic antibiotics were discontinued in children with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) who initially presented with febrile urinary tract infection (UTI) after they were toilet-trained and had no evidence of infection or voiding dysfunction.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: Febrile UTI developed in 11 patients (10 percent) at a mean 17.2 months after discontinuation of antibiotics, eight of whom had grade III to IV VUR and three of whom had grade II VUR.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: Renal ultrasound demonstrated new findings suggestive of scarring in two patients, both of whom had a febrile UTI;

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: DMSA renal scan confirmed the presence of small cortical defects.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: Patients who developed subsequent UTIs were more likely to have higher grades of VUR (ie, grades III to V) and developed symptoms of bladder/bowel dysfunction.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: In 10 of the 11 patients with UTIs after discontinuation of prophylaxis, surgical correction successfully corrected VUR.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: These results demonstrate discontinuation of antibiotics is reasonable in infection-free patients with persistent low-grade VUR following toilet-training, but this group of patients may not have needed the initial medical therapy to prevent recurrent infection and scarring.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: In another retrospective study of 185 patients with VUR who discontinued antibiotics (mean age 6.2 years), 55 developed UTIs (30 percent) at a mean follow-up of two years.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: This study was unable to identify any clinical parameter that was predictive of a UTI after discontinuation of prophylactic antibiotics.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: This is reflected by some variation between two authors' approach as follows: In both our practices, we continue medical therapy until there is resolution or diminishment of reflux to grade I level in children with VUR who do not have bladder and bowel dysfunction.

section.label: Discontinuation of medical therapy
section.fragment: Both authors maintain medical therapy in children with bladder and bowel dysfunction until there is significant improvement in both voiding symptoms and severity of reflux.

section.label: Surgical therapy
section.fragment: Although some studies suggest that it is not necessary to document resolution after open surgical repair, it is our practice to document success of the surgery by a postoperative VCUG or RNC in patients who have undergone surgical correction.

section.label: up
section.fragment: Following the resolution of VUR either spontaneously or surgically, long-term follow-up should be provided because of the association of VUR with significant renal sequelae.

section.label: up
section.fragment: The AUA guidelines suggest annual assessments, which include measurements of growth (height and weight) and blood pressure, and urinalysis to detect proteinuria or bacteria, through adolescence.

section.label: up
section.fragment: Families should be aware of the potential complications of hypertension, impaired renal function, and the increased risk of VUR in first-degree relatives.

section.label: up
section.fragment: DMSA renal scan is the most sensitive measure for detecting renal scarring.

section.label: up
section.fragment: Renal ultrasound is not as sensitive in detecting renal scars as DMSA scan, and as a result has not been as useful in follow-up.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Current treatment is based upon the long-held view that vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), when combined with urinary tract infection (UTI), is a risk factor for renal scarring, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Over the past 30 to 40 years, therapy has been directed towards preventing the reflux of infected urine, thereby reducing renal injury.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: It remains unknown precisely how beneficial the treatment of children with VUR is because renal outcome data of patients treated for VUR compared with those who receive no treatment (surveillance) are lacking.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Our management is based upon the currently available data, prevention of pyelonephritis, likelihood of renal scarring (which is dependent upon the severity of reflux), the likelihood of spontaneous resolution of VUR, and patient/family preference.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Patients with VUR may also have voiding dysfunction and should be screened for this condition.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We suggest all children with grades III through V reflux be treated because they are at greatest risk for recurrent UTI, renal scarring, and hypertension.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: An alternative approach to therapeutic VUR intervention is a surveillance regimen of prompt treatment with intercurrent episodes of UTI.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Children with grade I to II reflux are at the lowest risk for renal scarring.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Medical treatment consists of prophylactic antibiotic therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, trimethoprim alone, or nitrofurantoin.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We suggest surgical rather than medical therapy in the following group of patients who are unlikely to have spontaneous resolution of their reflux and are at risk for renal scarring.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Grade V reflux in children over six years of age.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Patients who are treated medically or by observation require mandatory urine cultures whenever there are symptoms suggestive of UTI or unexplained fever, and monitoring by radionuclide cystogram for the continued presence of VUR.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: In our practice, yearly renal ultrasonography is performed in patients who are medically treated, and dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) renal scan is performed in patients with ultrasound results that suggest renal scarring or poor renal growth, those with recurrent UTI, and patients with Grade III through V VUR.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Families should be aware of the association of VUR with increased risk of hypertension and chronic kidney disease.

feed.title: Long-term management and prevention of urinary tract infections in children

section.label: Recurrent symptoms
section.fragment: Breakthrough UTI are most common in girls.

section.label: Recurrent symptoms
section.fragment: Families of young children with UTI should receive instruction about the risk of recurrent UTI and be advised to seek medical attention promptly for fever and/or urinary symptoms.

section.label: Recurrent symptoms
section.fragment: The evaluation of these episodes should include urinalysis, urine culture, or both.

section.label: Children with VUR
section.fragment: The long-term management and follow-up of children with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) are discussed separately.

section.label: Children with bowel and bladder dysfunction
section.fragment: An important task in the management of children with UTI, especially those with recurrent UTI, is to identify underlying bowel and bladder dysfunction, which is an important risk factor.

section.label: Children with bowel and bladder dysfunction
section.fragment: Treatment of bowel and bladder dysfunction reduces the likelihood of UTI recurrences and is associated with faster resolution of VUR.

section.label: Children with bowel and bladder dysfunction
section.fragment: The first steps in the treatment of bowel and bladder dysfunction include timed voiding (scheduled voids every two to three hours), "double" voiding (asking children to sit and urinate again right after they voided), avoidance of C's (carbonated drinks, caffeine, citrus, chocolate, and food colorants), and/or the use of laxatives for children with constipation.

section.label: Children with bowel and bladder dysfunction
section.fragment: In chronically constipated children, treatment with laxatives has been shown to significantly reduce recurrences of UTI.

section.label: PREVENTION OF RECURRENT UTI IN CHILDREN WITHOUT VUR
section.fragment: The discussion below focuses on prevention of recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI) in children who do not have vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), urinary obstruction, or bowel and bladder dysfunction.

section.label: Surveillance cultures
section.fragment: Routine surveillance cultures for asymptomatic children after their first UTI should not be performed.

section.label: Surveillance cultures
section.fragment: In a study comparing oral and intravenous antibiotics for UTI in children, routine surveillance of asymptomatic children did not enhance identification of true UTI episodes.

section.label: Surveillance cultures
section.fragment: Further, treatment of patients who have bacteriuria without symptoms is unproven and may be harmful.

section.label: Prophylaxis
section.fragment: Several randomized trials have evaluated the benefit of prophylactic antibiotics in preventing recurrent UTI in children, but most studies included only children with VUR.

section.label: Prophylaxis
section.fragment: A meta-analysis of individual data restricted to young children 2 to 24 months of age without VUR did not detect a benefit for prophylaxis in preventing recurrence.

section.label: Prophylaxis
section.fragment: two trials restricted enrollment to children with a first UTI and one trial included <30 percent of children with recurrent UTI.

section.label: Prophylaxis
section.fragment: Thus, although available data suggest that routine prophylactic antibiotics are not beneficial after a first UTI in children without VUR, there are few data to guide care of children with frequent recurrent UTIs.

section.label: Prophylaxis
section.fragment: We suggest antimicrobial prophylaxis in children without vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) who have frequent recurrent UTIs (three febrile UTIs in six months or four total UTIs in one year).

section.label: Prophylaxis
section.fragment: The management of children with VUR is discussed separately.

section.label: Cranberry juice
section.fragment: We do not routinely suggest cranberry juice for the prevention of recurrent UTI in children.

section.label: Cranberry juice
section.fragment: Meta-analysis of two studies limited to children with recurrent UTI also found no benefit.

section.label: Cranberry juice
section.fragment: Although cranberry juice in moderation is unlikely to be harmful, excessive intake may contribute to dental caries, diarrhea, and obesity.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Families of young children with urinary tract infection (UTI) should receive instruction about the risk of recurrent UTI and be advised to seek medical attention promptly for fever and/or urinary symptoms.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The evaluation for episodes of fever and/or urinary symptoms should include a properly collected urine specimen (using bladder catheterization in children who are not toilet trained) which is then sent for urinalysis, urine culture, or both.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Routine surveillance cultures in asymptomatic children after their first UTI are unnecessary.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We suggest antimicrobial prophylaxis in children without vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) who have frequent recurrent UTIs (three febrile UTIs in six months or four total UTIs in one year).

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or nitrofurantoin may be used for prophylaxis.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We do not routinely suggest cranberry juice for the prevention of recurrent UTI in children.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The long-term management and follow-up of children with vesicoureteral reflux are discussed separately.

feed.title: Presentation, diagnosis, and clinical course of vesicoureteral reflux

section.label: Primary VUR
section.fragment: The intravesical ureter length may be genetically dictated, which may explain the increased incidence in family members of patients with VUR.

section.label: Secondary VUR
section.fragment: Secondary VUR is a result of abnormally high pressure in the bladder that results in failure of the closure of the UVJ during bladder contraction.

section.label: Secondary VUR
section.fragment: The degree and chronicity of obstruction can influence the severity of VUR.

section.label: Secondary VUR
section.fragment: None of the data subsequently discussed are applicable to patients with secondary vesicoureteral reflux.

section.label: GENETICS
section.fragment: There is a strong genetic predisposition for primary vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) as documented by a systematic review of the literature that reported prevalence rates of 27.4 percent for siblings of a patient with VUR, and 35.7 percent for children of an affected parent.

section.label: GENETICS
section.fragment: Support for a strong genetic component was also demonstrated by a study of siblings from multiple gestation births that found a higher VUR rate in identical twins (12 out of 15 twin sets, 80 percent) compared with fraternal twins (11 out of 31 twin sets, 35 percent).

section.label: GENETICS
section.fragment: however, this gene does not appear to have a causative role in humans.

section.label: GENETICS
section.fragment: Genes that may play a role in familial VUR include those that encode SLIT2 protein and its receptor ROBO2, which play key roles in the formation of the ureter.

section.label: GENETICS
section.fragment: In one study, whole genome linkage and association in 320 families with at least two affected siblings failed to detect any association with six candidate genes (AGTR2, HNF1B, PAX2, RET, ROBO2, and UPKA3).

section.label: GENETICS
section.fragment: The authors conclude that a major locus may not be associated with VUR within affected European families.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: This variability is primarily due to differences in the definition of prenatal hydronephrosis and the indications for and timing of postnatal evaluation.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: In the larger of the systematic reviews conducted by the American Urological Association (AUA), prenatal hydronephrosis was defined as a renal pelvic diameter (RPD) >=4 mm during the second trimester and >=7 mm during the third trimester.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: RPD was not predictive of VUR.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: The extent of the neonatal evaluation required for infants prenatally diagnosed with hydronephrosis is controversial.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: However, one of the reservations for a full diagnostic evaluation is that the diagnosis of VUR is made only by VCUG or radionuclide cystogram (RNC).

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: Neither test is a benign procedure because of the need for catheterization, and risk of post-procedure urinary tract infection.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: Performing these studies in all neonates with antenatal hydronephrosis would subject a large number of patients without VUR to an invasive and costly procedure.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: A sensitive and less invasive screening test for VUR is therefore desirable.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: The following examples illustrate this controversy: In one retrospective study, almost 90 percent of patients with known VUR (previously detected by VCUG) had one of the following abnormalities on postnatal renal ultrasonography: increased diameter of the renal pelvis of greater than 7 mm, caliceal or ureteral dilatation, pelviureteral wall thickening, absence of renal corticomedullary differentiation, or findings suggestive of renal dysplasia.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: A second case series of 121 infants with prenatal hydronephrosis also reported that the risk of VUR increased as the postnatal diameter of the renal pelvis increased with a cut-off of 7 mm demonstrating a fair ability to predict VUR.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: Other studies, principally observational, have reported that 17 to 25 percent of neonates with a normal postnatal renal ultrasound have VUR detected by VCUG.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: These authors therefore recommended VCUG be performed on all infants with prenatal hydronephrosis.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: These studies, although flawed, provide the rationale for the following two approaches for evaluation of prenatal hydronephrosis: Postnatal renal ultrasound and VCUG are performed for all patients with prenatal hydronephrosis.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: Postnatal renal ultrasound alone is performed initially in all patients with prenatal hydronephrosis.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: A VCUG is performed only in patients with abnormalities on a postnatal renal ultrasound or who develop a UTI during observation.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: In our practice, we use the second two-step approach with an initial screening ultrasound for all patients with prenatal hydronephrosis consistent with the AUA and the European Association of Urology guidelines.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: VCUG is reserved for those with an abnormal ultrasound, those who develop a UTI on observation, or those who have a family history of VUR.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: VCUG is performed if there are other prenatally detected renal anomalies that increase the risk of VUR, such as ureteropelvic junction obstruction, ureteral duplication, bladder diverticulum, renal agenesis, renal ectopia, and multicystic dysplastic kidney.

section.label: Prenatal presentation
section.fragment: If a VCUG is to be performed, the procedure needs to be done in referral centers that have expertise both in catheterization and determination of radiation exposure in infants.

section.label: Our diagnostic approach
section.fragment: As discussed previously, the extent of the evaluation for infants prenatally diagnosed with hydronephrosis is controversial.

section.label: Our diagnostic approach
section.fragment: In our practice, we use the following approach: Repeat renal ultrasonography postdelivery.

section.label: Our diagnostic approach
section.fragment: If the VCUG is normal and the hydronephrosis is grade 3 or 4 or greater that 12 mm, a functional renal scan with Tc99mMAG3 is suggested to detect possible obstruction.

section.label: Our diagnostic approach
section.fragment: If the postnatal renal ultrasonography is normal or demonstrates mild hydronephrosis, we repeat renal sonography two or three months later.

section.label: Our diagnostic approach
section.fragment: If hydronephrosis persists, a follow-up renal sonogram is performed six months late.

section.label: Our diagnostic approach
section.fragment: If the hydronephrosis worsens at any state, we proceed to a radionuclide cystogram.

section.label: Clinical findings and course
section.fragment: There is a male predominance in patients with VUR who present prenatally.

section.label: Clinical findings and course
section.fragment: In one study of 155 consecutive infants with VUR, 75 percent were males and patients with grade V reflux were almost exclusively male.

section.label: Clinical findings and course
section.fragment: VUR spontaneously resolved in 29 of 32 patients (91 percent) with low-grade reflux (grades I to III).

section.label: Clinical findings and course
section.fragment: In patients with high-grade reflux (grades IV and V), VUR resolved in 2 of 11 patients.

section.label: Clinical findings and course
section.fragment: In a second study of 25 patients diagnosed prenatally, VUR resolved in 3 of 10 patients with grade IV or V reflux and in 10 of 15 patients with grade I to III reflux.

section.label: Clinical findings and course
section.fragment: In a third study of 115 infants (median age 2.7 months) with high-grade VUR (grades III to V), VUR resolved in 26 percent of these high-grade cases.

section.label: Decrease renal parenchyma (scarring)
section.fragment: In infants who present prenatally, decrease renal parenchyma formation (eg, renal hypoplasia and dysplasia) is often associated with severe reflux.

section.label: Decrease renal parenchyma (scarring)
section.fragment: As an example, in the previously mentioned study, 3 of the 11 patients with grade IV and V reflux had evidence of primary renal scarring detected by radionuclide renal scan at a median age of three months (range two to eight months) before any clinical evidence of UTI.

section.label: Postnatal presentation
section.fragment: Postnatal diagnosis of VUR usually is made after a UTI, and less commonly, it is detected after screening of family members (eg, a child or sibling) of an index case.

section.label: Postnatal presentation
section.fragment: Children with a febrile UTI have a higher risk for abnormalities of the genitourinary tract, including VUR and obstructive uropathy.

section.label: Postnatal presentation
section.fragment: As previously mentioned, the diagnosis of VUR is made only by demonstrating reflux of urine from the bladder to the collecting system either by a VCUG or radionuclide cystogram (RNC).

section.label: Postnatal presentation
section.fragment: Among children with VUR who present after an initial UTI, 95 percent will have mild or moderate reflux (ie, grades I to III).

section.label: Postnatal presentation
section.fragment: The approach including indications, timing, and choice of modality for imaging in children with UTI is discussed separately.

section.label: Postnatal presentation
section.fragment: Children with VUR diagnosed after an initial UTI are also more likely to have dysfunctional voiding.

section.label: Clinical course
section.fragment: In the majority of cases, VUR will spontaneously resolve, as illustrated by a retrospective study from a single tertiary center that reviewed the outcome of 2462 patients with primary VUR diagnosed between 1998 and 2006.

section.label: Clinical course
section.fragment: The following findings were noted: VUR resolved spontaneously in 1257 patients (51 percent) at a mean duration of two years.

section.label: Clinical course
section.fragment: Factors associated with spontaneous resolution included age of diagnosis under one year of age, lower grades of VUR, prenatal hydronephrosis, and unilateral involvement.

section.label: Clinical course
section.fragment: Indications for surgery included breakthrough febrile UTI, renal scarring detected by renal radionuclide scan, nonresolution, and parent preference.

section.label: Clinical course
section.fragment: The oldest group of children (5 to 10 years of age) with bilateral reflux had less than 20 percent resolution over five years.

section.label: Clinical course
section.fragment: In contrast, there was a 70 percent resolution rate in the youngest group of children (one to two years) with unilateral disease.

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: Evaluation of scarring by dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) renal scan is more sensitive than ultrasonography.

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: A follow-up DMSA scan performed one to two years later demonstrated renal scarring in 26 percent of the patients including 43 without VUR (19 percent) and 37 with VUR (46 percent).

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: In another Swedish study of 115 infants (median age at diagnosis 2.7 months) with high grade VUR (ie, grades III, IV and V), renal parenchymal damage detected by either DMSA or MAG3 renal scan was observed in 98 patients (85 percent) at study inclusion;

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: All patients received antibiotic prophylaxis.

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: At a median follow-up of 5 years, renal parenchymal abnormalities were demonstrated in 103 patients (90 percent).

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: Ninety-one of the 193 patients who participated in the follow-up evaluation had VUR with grades III through V.

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: Overall, 22 unilateral renal parenchymal defects were detected in 15 percent of 150 patients who underwent ultrasound testing at follow-up: 18 of the defects occurred after the episode of UTI, and all but one of the 22 defects occurred in patients with grade III-V VUR.

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: In addition, kidney growth retardation was detected by renal ultrasound in five patients (3 percent of tested patients), all of whom had VUR with grade III-V VUR.

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: At the last follow-up visit, all patients had normal renal function and blood pressure, and no patients had hematuria or proteinuria.

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: However, because most patients with grade III-V VUR received medical intervention (eg, antimicrobial prophylaxis) and 45 percent underwent antireflux surgery, it remains uncertain whether or not the favorable clinical outcome was a result of, or despite, active therapeutic measures.

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: In contrast, a retrospective study of 389 Korean children with first febrile urinary tract infection (mean age 14.9 months) did not find an association between reflux grade and scar formation based upon follow-up DMSA scan performed 6 months (range 5 to 7 months) after the urinary tract infection.

section.label: Renal scarring and severity of reflux
section.fragment: However, other findings in this study were similar to those of the first Swedish study including a 32 percent risk of VUR and an increased likelihood of scarring in patients with VUR compared to those without VUR (50 versus 18 percent).

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: However, this long-held belief that reflux alone can lead to progressive chronic kidney disease due to renal scarring and potentially ESRD, has been increasingly questioned.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: Another view, as noted previously, is that VUR is not an important risk factor for renal scarring and potential chronic kidney disease (CKD) but is a marker for abnormal renal development, which results in decreased formation of renal parenchyma referred to as primary renal scarring.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: Support for this view that VUR does not play a role in renal scar formation but is a marker for abnormal renal development is provided by the following observations: A population-based cohort study of children with first recognized febrile UTI demonstrated that an increased risk for "renal scarring" was principally found in young boys with VUR.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: These boys did not have a previous history of recurrent UTI and their kidneys were globally small, with smooth renal outlines on radiologic imaging consistent with renal hypoplasia or dysplasia.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: The authors concluded that children with VUR could be divided into those with primary "scarring" due to due malformation (who are predominately male) and those with acquired scarring.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: Data from a population-based chronic kidney registry from Italy suggested the primary cause of renal failure in children with VUR was congenital renal hypoplasia or dysplasia.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: Candidate genes have been identified in animal models that may play a role in the regulation of ureteric and renal development.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: The rate of reflux-related ESRD has not changed in Australia and New Zealand over the four decades from the 1960s to 1990s despite the change in general clinical practice of proactively identifying children with VUR and treating them with either surgical correction or antibiotic prophylaxis.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: The viewpoint that CKD results from renal maldevelopment (hypoplasia and dysplasia) associated with VUR has led to questioning the utility of any regimen directed at identifying or treating VUR.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: Although there are limited data comparing the outcome of children with VUR who receive treatment (either medical or surgical) to those who receive no directed intervention, the results do not conclusively demonstrate whether or not therapeutic interventions affect long-term renal outcome.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: Because of the severity of the potential poor outcome and the paucity of conclusive evidence, we continue to regard VUR as a risk for recurrent pyelonephritis and possible renal scarring.

section.label: ROLE IN RENAL SCARRING AND CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE
section.fragment: As a result, until large clinical studies show similar renal outcomes (chronic kidney disease and renal scarring) in children who do not receive treatment for VUR compared to those who do, we continue to suggest imaging studies to detect possible VUR in at-risk children and intervention in those diagnosed with significant VUR.

section.label: FURTHER EVALUATION
section.fragment: Because of the association between vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) and renal scarring, which may lead to chronic kidney disease (CKD), 2010 revised guidelines from the American Urological Association state that an initial evaluation of the child's renal status, growth parameters, and blood pressure should be performed in any child with VUR.

section.label: FURTHER EVALUATION
section.fragment: In our practice, we incorporate these guidelines in our evaluation of a child with VUR as follows: A careful medical evaluation is performed, which includes measurement of height, weight, and blood pressure.

section.label: FURTHER EVALUATION
section.fragment: Urinalysis to detect proteinuria or pyuria.

section.label: FURTHER EVALUATION
section.fragment: If pyuria or bacteria is present, a urine culture should be obtained to screen for urinary tract infection (UTI).

section.label: FURTHER EVALUATION
section.fragment: DMSA renal scan may be obtained in patients who are at-risk for scarring.

section.label: Screening of family members
section.fragment: The screening of family members is controversial, with debate concerning the risk and benefits of screening because there are no data on the outcome of treated versus untreated first degree family members (ie, offspring or siblings) of a patient with VUR.

section.label: Screening of family members
section.fragment: However, there is a rate of renal damage of 14 percent in asymptomatic siblings.

section.label: Screening of family members
section.fragment: Unfortunately, a prospective randomized trial that could determine the optimal approach to managing siblings of patients with VUR is highly unlikely.

section.label: Screening of family members
section.fragment: In one study, hypothetical modeling demonstrated a relatively high cost of universal screening with limited benefits in reducing the number of febrile UTI in siblings of children with VUR.

section.label: Screening of family members
section.fragment: The estimated costs and effectiveness of averting febrile UTIs was heavily dependent on the screening age (screening was most cost-effective for children less than one year of age) and the assumption that antibiotic prophylaxis was effective in reducing the risk of UTI.

section.label: Screening of family members
section.fragment: These observations are not supportive of routine screening of siblings of patients with VUR.

section.label: Screening of family members
section.fragment: There appears to be a significant risk of renal scarring in siblings of patients with high grade VUR.

section.label: Screening of family members
section.fragment: In an observational study of 300 siblings of 259 patients with VUR (ie, grades between III and V), almost a quarter of the 212 siblings who underwent DMSA renal scan had evidence of renal scarring.

section.label: Screening of family members
section.fragment: In our practice, we screen siblings and children of patients with VUR because of the increased familial incidence of VUR.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is the retrograde passage of urine from the bladder into the upper urinary tract.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Current management is based upon the long-held belief that VUR, when associated with febrile urinary tract infection, is a risk factor for renal scarring that can result in an increased risk of hypertension and chronic kidney disease.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: However, this premise has been increasingly questioned with data supporting an alternate viewpoint that VUR does not play a causative role in renal scarring but merely is a marker for abnormal renal development.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Until such data are available, we continue to regard VUR as a risk factor for recurrent pyelonephritis and possible renal scarring.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: As a result, we suggest diagnostic evaluation to detect possible VUR in at-risk children and therapeutic intervention in those with clinically significant VUR.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The diagnosis of VUR is based upon the demonstration of reflux of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract by either contrast voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) or radionuclide cystogram (RNC).

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The severity of VUR is dependent upon the degree of retrograde filling and dilation of the renal collecting system demonstrated by VCUG or RNC.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: In our practice, postnatal renal ultrasound alone is performed initially in all patients with prenatal hydronephrosis.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: A VCUG is performed only in patients with abnormalities on a postnatal renal ultrasound or in those with a strong family history of VUR.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: An alternate approach is performing postnatal renal ultrasound and VCUG for all patients with prenatal hydronephrosis.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We suggest that the following 2010 American Urologic Association guidelines be used in the initial evaluation of children with VUR.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Medical evaluation including measurements of height, weight, and blood pressure and identifying any patient with symptoms indicative of voiding dysfunction.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Renal imaging with either renal ultrasound or dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) renal scan.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We suggest initial screening with sonography for VUR in siblings and children of any patient with VUR.

feed.title: Urinary tract infections in infants and children older than one month: Acute management, imaging, an

section.label: Goals
section.fragment: The goals of treatment for urinary tract infections (UTI) include: Elimination of infection and prevention of urosepsis.

section.label: Goals
section.fragment: Acute management of UTI in children consists of antimicrobial therapy to treat the acute infection and evaluation for possible predisposing factors (eg, urologic abnormalities).

section.label: Decision to hospitalize
section.fragment: Most infants older than two months with UTI can be safely managed as outpatients as long as close follow-up is possible.

section.label: ANTIBIOTIC THERAPY
section.fragment: The effectiveness of antimicrobial therapy for urinary tract infections (UTI) is demonstrated by the change in mortality between the pre- and post-antibiotic eras.

section.label: ANTIBIOTIC THERAPY
section.fragment: In contrast, when UTI are appropriately treated with antibiotics, acute complications (eg, renal abscess, death) are uncommon.

section.label: ANTIBIOTIC THERAPY
section.fragment: Antimicrobial therapy for children with presumed UTI depends upon a number of factors, including the age of the child, severity of illness, presence of vomiting, duration of fever before presentation, underlying medical and/or urologic problems, and the antimicrobial resistance patterns in the community.

section.label: Empiric therapy
section.fragment: Decisions regarding the initiation of empiric antimicrobial therapy for UTI are best made on a case-by-case basis based upon the probability of UTI, which is determined by demographic and clinical factors.

section.label: Empiric therapy
section.fragment: We suggest that empiric antimicrobial therapy be initiated immediately after appropriate urine collection in children with suspected UTI and a positive urinalysis.

section.label: Empiric therapy
section.fragment: This is particularly true for children who are at increased risk for renal scarring if UTI is not promptly treated, including children who present with: Fever (especially >39oC [102.2oF] or >48 hours).

section.label: Choice of agent
section.fragment: it accounts for approximately 80 percent of UTI in children.

section.label: Choice of agent
section.fragment: We recommend that empiric therapy for UTI in infants and children include an antibiotic that provides adequate coverage for E. coli.

section.label: Choice of agent
section.fragment: Increased resistance to extended-spectrum cephalosporins (cefotaxime, ceftazidime, cefepime), has been reported in children receiving prophylactic antibiotics.

section.label: Choice of agent
section.fragment: Third-generation cephalosporins (eg, cefpodoxime, cefixime, cefdinir, ceftibuten, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone) and aminoglycosides (eg, gentamicin, amikacin) are appropriate first-line agents for empiric treatment of UTI in children.

section.label: Choice of agent
section.fragment: However, these drugs are not effective in treating Enterococcus and should not be used as monotherapy for patients in whom enterococcal UTI is suspected (eg, those with a urinary catheter in place, instrumentation of the urinary tract, or an anatomical abnormality).

section.label: Choice of agent
section.fragment: Hydration status and renal function should be assessed in patients who are treated with aminoglycosides.

section.label: Oral therapy
section.fragment: Most children older than two months of age who are not vomiting can be treated with orally administered antimicrobials.

section.label: Oral therapy
section.fragment: We suggest a third-generation cephalosporin (eg, cefixime cefdinir, ceftibuten) as the first-line oral agent in the treatment of UTI in children without genitourinary abnormalities.

section.label: Oral therapy
section.fragment: In a randomized, controlled trial of 306 children 1 to 24 months of age with a febrile UTI, oral therapy with cefixime for 14 days was as effective as intravenous therapy with cefotaxime for three days followed by oral therapy with cefixime.

section.label: Oral therapy
section.fragment: Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate (50 mg/kg per day in three divided doses) also was shown to be as effective as parenteral therapy followed by oral therapy in a multicenter, randomized trial.

section.label: Oral therapy
section.fragment: In a child with a penicillin and cephalosporin allergy, treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), or ciprofloxacin (if the local resistance rates to TMP-SMX are known to be high) and close follow-up of the antimicrobial sensitivity results is a reasonable strategy.

section.label: Oral therapy
section.fragment: Amoxicillin and ampicillin are not routinely recommended for empiric therapy because of the high rate of resistance of E. coli.

section.label: Oral therapy
section.fragment: Similarly, amoxicillin-clavulanate, first-generation cephalosporins (eg, cephalexin), and TMP-SMX should be used with caution because of the increasing rates of resistance to these drugs in some communities.

section.label: Oral therapy
section.fragment: Ciprofloxacin should not be used as a first-line agent.

section.label: Oral therapy
section.fragment: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) Committee on Infectious Diseases recommends that the use of ciprofloxacin for UTI in children be limited to UTI caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or other multidrug-resistant, gram-negative bacteria.

section.label: Oral therapy
section.fragment: Oral agents that are excreted in the urine but do not achieve therapeutic serum concentrations (eg, nalidixic acid, nitrofurantoin) should not be used to treat UTI in febrile infants and young children in whom renal involvement is likely because parenchymal and serum concentrations may be insufficient to treat pyelonephritis or urosepsis.

section.label: Parenteral therapy
section.fragment: Third- or fourth-generation cephalosporins (eg, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefepime) and aminoglycosides (eg, gentamicin) are appropriate first-line parenteral agents for empiric treatment of UTI in children.

section.label: Parenteral therapy
section.fragment: Ampicillin should be included if enterococcal UTI is suspected.

section.label: Recent antibiotic exposure
section.fragment: Recent exposure to antibiotics, whether for treatment of an infection or as antimicrobial prophylaxis, is an important consideration in the choice of empiric antibiotic therapy.

section.label: Recurrent UTI
section.fragment: Review of the antimicrobial susceptibilities of the most recent urinary pathogens can be helpful in choosing empiric therapy for children with recurrent UTI.

section.label: Duration of therapy
section.fragment: In a systematic review, short course antimicrobial therapy (two to four days) was as effective as standard duration (7 to 14 days) therapy in eradicating bacteria in children with suspected lower urinary tract infection (ie, afebrile children).

section.label: Duration of therapy
section.fragment: However, little evidence is available to guide duration of antimicrobial therapy in children with febrile UTIs.

section.label: Duration of therapy
section.fragment: A multicenter trial, sponsored by the National Institutes of Health, is being conducted to determine the efficacy of short-course therapy for UTI in children.

section.label: Duration of therapy
section.fragment: In the meantime, we suggest a longer course of therapy for febrile children (usually 10 days) and a short course of therapy (three to five days) for immune competent children presenting without fever.

section.label: Clinical response
section.fragment: In a review of 288 children younger than two years who were admitted to a tertiary-care children's hospital with febrile UTI, 89 percent were afebrile within 48 hours of antimicrobial therapy.

section.label: Repeat urine culture
section.fragment: Several observational studies suggest there is little utility in repeating the urine culture in children with UTI who are treated with an antibiotic to which their uropathogen is susceptible.

section.label: Repeat urine culture
section.fragment: Accordingly, it is not necessary to routinely obtain repeat urine cultures during antimicrobial therapy to document sterilization of the urine, provided that the child has had the expected clinical response and the uropathogen is susceptible to the antibiotic that is used for treatment.

section.label: Repeat urine culture
section.fragment: However, urine cultures should be performed after 48 hours of therapy if the patient fails to respond clinically or if the uropathogen is not susceptible (intermediate or resistant) to the antibiotic that is being used for treatment.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: A meta-analysis of individual data in infants and young children (2 to 24 months) without VUR and with VUR of grades I to IV did not detect a benefit for prophylaxis in preventing recurrence.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: However, some of the included trials had methodologic problems potentially biasing results toward no effect (eg, insufficient power; lack of blinding; non-stringent diagnostic criteria; inclusion of uncircumcised boys, which limits generalizability to populations where most boys are circumcised; and misclassification of asymptomatic bacteriuria as recurrent UTIs).

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: the reduction in absolute risk was greatest for children with grade III-V VUR (6.8 percentage points compared with 5.4 percentage points for children with grade I to II VUR and 1.8 percentage points for children without VUR).

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: More conclusive evidence on the benefits of antimicrobial prophylaxis is expected from the ongoing randomized intervention for vesicoureteral reflux (RIVUR) trial comparing TMP-SMX prophylaxis and placebo in 607 children (two months to six years) with grade I to IV VUR following UTI.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: However, if a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is performed and demonstrates grade III or higher VUR, we suggest antimicrobial prophylaxis.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: The United Kingdom's National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline for UTI in children indicates that antibiotic prophylaxis should not be routinely recommended in infants and children following their first UTI, but may be warranted after recurrent UTI.

section.label: ADJUNCTIVE THERAPIES
section.fragment: Renal parenchymal inflammation during urinary tract infections (UTI) may lead to renal scarring, although the predisposing factors are not well understood.

section.label: ADJUNCTIVE THERAPIES
section.fragment: The role of renal parenchymal inflammation in the development of renal scars, and the potential role of anti-inflammatory agents in preventing renal scars has been evaluated in several studies.

section.label: ADJUNCTIVE THERAPIES
section.fragment: An observational study demonstrated that dexamethasone decreased urinary levels of interleukin-6 and interleukin-8 in children, suggesting a possible role for glucocorticoids in the prevention of scar formation.

section.label: ADJUNCTIVE THERAPIES
section.fragment: Treatment with methylprednisolone was associated with decreased renal scarring at six months (33 versus 60 percent in the methylprednisolone and placebo groups, respectively) without significant adverse effects, relapse, or recurrence.

section.label: ADJUNCTIVE THERAPIES
section.fragment: Results of this small study are difficult to generalize because enrollment required 1) performance of a renal scintigram within 48 hours of diagnosis, which was not conducted in all patients, and 2) severe renal involvement in children who were all hospitalized.

section.label: ADJUNCTIVE THERAPIES
section.fragment: Additional studies are necessary to confirm these results and to determine the optimum glucocorticoid regimen before adjunctive glucocorticoids are routinely recommended in the treatment of UTI in children.

section.label: Rationale
section.fragment: The rationale for imaging in young children with urinary tract infections (UTI) is to identify abnormalities of the genitourinary tract that require additional evaluation or management (eg, obstructive uropathies, dilating vesicoureteral reflux [VUR]).

section.label: Rationale
section.fragment: If such abnormalities are detected, steps can be taken to modify the risk of subsequent renal damage (eg, surgical intervention or antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent recurrent UTI).

section.label: Rationale
section.fragment: The ultimate value of detecting anatomic or functional abnormalities of the urinary tract depends upon the effectiveness of the interventions designed to prevent recurrent UTI and renal scarring.

section.label: Rationale
section.fragment: Prompt diagnosis and effective treatment of recurrent febrile UTI and treatment of bowel and bladder dysfunction that predisposes many children to UTI may be more important than identifying anatomic or functional genitourinary abnormalities after the first febrile UTI in preventing renal scarring.

section.label: Ultrasonography
section.fragment: RBUS can also identify renal or perirenal abscess or pyonephrosis in children with acute UTI who fail to improve with antimicrobial therapy.

section.label: Ultrasonography
section.fragment: Given the potentially large benefit of detecting correctible malformations for a small number of children and the low risk of harm, we suggest RBUS for the following children: Children younger than two years of age with a first febrile UTI.

section.label: Ultrasonography
section.fragment: Children of any age with recurrent febrile UTIs.

section.label: Ultrasonography
section.fragment: Children of any age with a UTI who have a family history of renal or urologic disease, poor growth, or hypertension.

section.label: Ultrasonography
section.fragment: The United Kingdom's National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline on UTI in children recommends RBUS for infants younger than six months and for children older than six months who have atypical or recurrent UTI.

section.label: Timing
section.fragment: In infants and young children with unusually severe illness or failure to improve as expected after initiation of antimicrobial therapy, RBUS should be performed as soon as possible during the acute phase of illness to identify complications (eg, renal or perirenal abscess, pyonephrosis).

section.label: Timing
section.fragment: However, for infants and young children who respond as expected to appropriate antimicrobial therapy, RBUS should be performed after the acute phase (to reduce the risk of false positive results secondary to renal inflammation during the acute episode).

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is the retrograde passage of urine from the bladder into the upper urinary tract.

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: Approximately 40 percent of young children with a first febrile UTI have VUR.

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: The voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the test of choice to establish the presence and degree of VUR.

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: The utility of the routine VCUG in the evaluation of children with UTI has been questioned.

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: The controversy centers on the changing view of the role of VUR in the development of renal damage and progressive kidney disease (VUR is neither necessary nor sufficient for the development of renal scars) and the uncertainty regarding the effectiveness of medical or surgical management of VUR in reducing the risk of renal scarring.

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: The risk of renal scarring is increased in children with VUR compared with children without VUR (41 versus 17 percent in a systematic review) and increases with increasing grades of VUR.

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: Pending results of the ongoing randomized intervention for vesicoureteral reflux (RIVUR) trial comparing trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) prophylaxis and placebo in 600 children (two months to six years) with grade I to IV VUR following UTI, we suggest VCUG to evaluate possible VUR for: Children of any age with two or more febrile UTIs.

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: Children of any age with a first febrile UTI who have a family history of renal or urologic disease;

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: children with poor growth or hypertension.

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: Urinary tract anomalies are more frequent among children with UTI caused by pathogens other than E. coli.

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: If a VCUG is performed and demonstrates grade III or higher VUR, we suggest antimicrobial prophylaxis.

section.label: Voiding cystourethrogram
section.fragment: The recommendation is to postpone the VCUG until the second febrile UTI unless there are atypical or complex clinical circumstances or the RBUS reveals hydronephrosis, scarring, or other findings suggestive of high-grade (IV or V) VUR or obstructive uropathy.

section.label: Timing
section.fragment: To avoid the use of prophylactic antibiotics in children without VUR, we prefer to conduct VCUGs during the last days of antimicrobial therapy or immediately after completion of antimicrobial therapy for UTI.

section.label: Renal scintigraphy
section.fragment: Renal scintigraphy using dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) can be used to detect acute pyelonephritis and renal scarring in the acute and chronic settings, respectively.

section.label: Renal scintigraphy
section.fragment: DMSA scans are expensive, invasive, and expose children to radiation (the pediatric effective dose estimate ranges from 0.3 to 3 mSV).

section.label: Renal scintigraphy
section.fragment: The role of renal scintigraphy in the management of children with acute UTI is controversial.

section.label: Renal scintigraphy
section.fragment: Furthermore, since most young febrile children with UTI have pyelonephritis and a positive DMSA, this strategy may lead to identification of a large number of children who may or may not be at risk for future UTI.

section.label: Renal scintigraphy
section.fragment: In a systematic review of 33 studies, approximately 60 percent of children with initial UTI had DMSA scans consistent with acute pyelonephritis in the acute phase of illness, but only 15 percent had renal scarring at follow-up.

section.label: Renal scintigraphy
section.fragment: It is unclear how to best manage children with positive acute-phase DMSA scan.

section.label: Renal scintigraphy
section.fragment: Careful clinical follow-up of all children with UTI may obviate the need for routine DMSA.

section.label: Renal scintigraphy
section.fragment: We suggest not using DMSA in the routine evaluation of children with first UTI.

section.label: Renal scintigraphy
section.fragment: The NICE guidelines recommend DMSA four to six months after acute infection for children younger than three years with atypical or recurrent UTI and for children older than three years with recurrent UTI.

section.label: UP
section.fragment: Parents of infants and young children who have been treated for a febrile UTI and children with bowel and bladder dysfunction (a risk factor for recurrent UTI) should be instructed to seek prompt evaluation for subsequent febrile illnesses to ensure prompt recognition and treatment of recurrent UTI.

section.label: UP
section.fragment: Primary care follow-up for infants and young children who have had a febrile UTI should include regular monitoring of height, weight, and blood pressure.

section.label: PROGNOSIS
section.fragment: The short-term outcome of first urinary tract infection (UTI) in children (<19 years) was described in a systematic review of 33 studies, including 4891 children: Twenty-five percent had vesicoureteral reflux (VUR);

section.label: PROGNOSIS
section.fragment: VUR was associated with an increased risk of developing acute pyelonephritis (relative risk [RR] 1.5, 95% CI 1.1-1.9) and renal scarring (RR 2.6, 95% CI 1.7-3.9);

section.label: PROGNOSIS
section.fragment: Fifteen percent (95% CI 11-18 percent) of children had evidence of renal scarring on follow-up dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan (5 to 24 months later);

section.label: PROGNOSIS
