section.fragment: Predicting which children with UTI will develop long-term sequelae remains difficult.

section.label: PROGNOSIS
section.fragment: The large majority of children with UTI have no long-term sequelae, as illustrated by the following studies: In a study of 111 high-risk girls who were followed for 6 to 32 years after their initial UTI, only seven (6 percent) had decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR), and none developed chronic kidney disease.

section.label: PROGNOSIS
section.fragment: In another study of 68 children with history of urographic renal scarring who were followed for 16 to 26 years after their index UTI, median GFR and mean 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure were no different in children with and without urographic renal scarring.

section.label: PROGNOSIS
section.fragment: No child developed chronic kidney disease.

section.label: PROGNOSIS
section.fragment: In a study of 226 children with UTI followed for one to 41 years, two developed chronic kidney disease that appeared to be attributable to the UTIs.

section.label: PROGNOSIS
section.fragment: The prognosis for children with nonfebrile UTI is discussed separately.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Most children with urinary tract infection (UTI) can be managed as outpatients.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Indications for hospitalization may include age <2 months, immunocompromised patient, vomiting or inability to tolerate oral medication, lack of outpatient follow-up, and failure to respond to outpatient therapy.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Empiric antimicrobial therapy immediately after appropriate urine collection is warranted in children with suspected UTI and a positive urinalysis.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: This is particularly true for young children with fever (especially if >39oC [102.2oF] or >48 hours), ill appearance, costovertebral angle tenderness, known immune deficiency, or known urologic abnormality.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We recommend that empiric therapy for UTI in children include an antibiotic that provides adequate coverage for Escherichia coli.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We suggest a third-generation cephalosporin (eg, cefixime, cefdinir, ceftibuten) as the first-line oral agent in the treatment of UTI in children without genitourinary abnormalities.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Third- or fourth-generation cephalosporins (eg, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefepime) and aminoglycosides (eg, gentamicin) are appropriate first-line parenteral agents for empiric treatment of UTI in children.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Febrile children are usually treated for 10 days.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Afebrile children are usually treated for shorter periods (3 to 5 days).

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Renal bladder ultrasonography (RBUS) should be performed as soon as possible to evaluate the presence of renal abscess or surgically correctable anatomic abnormalities or obstruction.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We suggest routine RBUS after first febrile UTI in children younger than two years who did not have normal prenatal ultrasonography at a reputable center at >30 to 32 weeks of gestation.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We also suggest RBUS for children of any age with recurrent febrile UTIs and children of any age with a first UTI who have poor growth, hypertension, or a family history of renal or urologic disease.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: In contrast to earlier suggestions for evaluation after an initial episode, we now suggest voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) to evaluate possible vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) for children of any age with >=2 febrile UTIs or a first febrile UTI and any of the following: a family history of renal or urologic disease;

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The majority of children with UTI have no long-term sequelae.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Prediction of long-term sequelae in children with UTI remains difficult.
